text:
In this part we figure out whether the difficulty of long range putts, mid range putts, or short range puts makes more of a difference to the score.

title: About
text:
Hi! My name is Zephan Shivam, and I’m a middle schooler from Austin, Texas.
You can see this project and much more at my github, https://github.com/PythonGoaler. If you want to contact me directly, you can contact me at my email, fearlessfan03 at gmail dot com.
I made this project because I’m passionate about golf and I wanted to explore what affects the score the most. If you want to see details, here is my github repo - https://github.com/PythonGoaler/golf-score-analyzing
This project was created as a part of Kane’s Data Sciece Bootcamp - https://bootcamp.davidkane.info/.

In this part, we try to figure out which of driving accuracy, approach shots, shots around the green, or putting has the most impact on the score.

In this part, we analyze whether the average score on a par 3, par 4, or par 5 affects the score the most.























Slope of Par 3 Graph:


17.1019 


Slope of Par 4 Graph:


17.22147 


Slope of Par 5 Graph:


9.600936 


Calculating the slopes, we see that the par 4 score has the most effect on the total score. However, the difference between the effect the par 4s and par 3s have on the score is almost negligible.

title: Analyzing PGA Data
text:
This project analyzes PGA data. It looks at many different variables around the course and sees whether they have an effect on the score. This project compares this effect to the effect of other similar variables, to extract interesting, intruiging data about golf.
 


Here’s one such comparison

title: Analyzing PGA Data
section: Here’s one such comparison. This graph compares yardage and score.
text: Here’s one such comparison. This graph compares yardage and score.

library(tidyverse) library(patchwork) golf_data <- read_csv(“dg_new_course_table.csv”) filtered_golf_data <- filter(golf_data, fw_width < 40)
p1 <- golf_data %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = fw_width, y = adj_score_to_par)) + geom_point() + labs(x = “Fairway Width”, y = “Score”) + theme(plot.title = element_text(face = “bold”)) + annotate(“label”, x = 30, y = 3.5, label = “Most of the data is here”, color = “black”, size = 3, arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.5, “cm”)))
p2 <- filtered_golf_data %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = fw_width, y = adj_score_to_par)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = “loess”, se = FALSE) + labs(x = “Fairway Width”, y = ““) + theme(plot.title = element_text(face =”bold”))
p1 + p2

library(tidyverse) library(patchwork) golf_data <- read_csv(“dg_new_course_table.csv”) filtered_golf_data <- filter(golf_data, fw_width < 40)
p1 <- golf_data %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = fw_width, y = adj_score_to_par)) + geom_point() + labs(x = “Fairway Width”, y = “Score”) + theme(plot.title = element_text(face = “bold”)) + annotate(“label”, x = 30, y = 3.5, label = “Most of the data is here”, color = “black”, size = 3, arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.5, “cm”)))
p2 <- filtered_golf_data %>% ggplot(mapping = aes(x = fw_width, y = adj_score_to_par)) + geom_point() + geom_smooth(method = “loess”, se = FALSE) + labs(x = “Fairway Width”, y = ““) + theme(plot.title = element_text(face =”bold”))
p1 + p2

Relation between driving distance and score










There is not much of a correlation, which seems suprising, but makes sense when we look at the relation between accuracy and distance.











We see that the accuracy goes down when the driving distance increases, which is why driving distance is not a huge factor towards the
